title: [CVE-2021-29156 on ForgeRock OpenAm] LDAP Injection in Webfinger Protocol!
vulnerability_information:
**Description:**
https://████████ is vulnerable to CVE-2021-29156. 

## References
* https://nvd.nist.gov/vuln/detail/CVE-2021-29156
* https://portswigger.net/research/hidden-oauth-attack-vectors
* https://github.com/projectdiscovery/nuclei-templates/blob/74db4223c11d27a934ca1c417aa4abca9e70ad35/cves/2021/CVE-2021-29156.yaml

## Impact

ForgeRock OpenAM before 13.5.1 allows LDAP injection via the Webfinger protocol. For example, an unauthenticated attacker can perform character-by-character retrieval of password hashes, or retrieve a session token or a private key.

## System Host(s)
████████

## Affected Product(s) and Version(s)


## CVE Numbers
CVE-2021-29156

## Steps to Reproduce
The references mentioned shall be helpful for successful reproduction.

## Suggested Mitigation/Remediation Actions

activities.message:
Greetings,
To validate your report, we require additional information.
Can you please answer the following questions?

Are you able to provide additional PoC for this ticket?

If you have any questions, please let me know.
Thanks again for supporting the DoD Vulnerability Disclosure Program.
Regar█████

Hi,

As per the ForgeRock OpenAM section at https://portswigger.net/research/hidden-oauth-attack-vectors, I am writing the following information as a PoC for this vulnerability in the given DoD target.

This reference states, "From the attacker perspective, it is possible to use LDAP filters to access different fiel███ of the user object stored in LDAP. One of the attack scenarios could be to enumerate a valid username:  `/openam/.well-known/webfinger?resource=http://x/████████*&rel=http://openid.net/specs/connect/1.0/issuer`. The server respon████ with the HTTP code 200 (OK) if any user name starts with "████*" and HTTP code 404 (Not Found) otherwise.".

Based on this, when I visit https://███████/openam/.well-known/webfinger?resource=http://x/██████████*&rel=http://openid.net/specs/connect/1.0/issuer, it issues a 200 OK response. This means, a user with first 3 characters of the username being "███████" exists.

Now, if I visit https://██████/openam/.well-known/webfinger?resource=http://x/binit*&rel=http://openid.net/specs/connect/1.0/issuer, it issues a 404 Not Found response. This means, a user with first 5 characters of the username being "binit" doesn't exist.

In similar way, we can retrieve the user's password hash character-by-character. The attack is not only limited to extraction of user attributes; it can also be used to extract a valid session token or private keys used for token signing.

With this much information, there is a solid proof that this domain is vulnerable to the given CVE ID. Also, you shall mark this vulnerability with a severity of Critical or High depending on your internal evaluation.

Thanks,
Binit

Thank you for the information. That example you provide has some steps to a POC. Right now, you have not provided a working POC. A step-by-step POC with clear instructions showing the issue and the impact is needed to push this forward. For example in this particular ticket we would want to see an enumerated username and proof that there is no lockout for attempting a bruteforce on the password associated with the enumerated username. Please provide one or feel free to self-close. Thanks!

Hi there,

I have written a couple of scripts to help in username enumeration and password enumeration. While looking over the Internet, I found out two usernames **██████████** and **███████** in the portal. So, I started running my password enumeration script, and it is running totally fine for a lot of combinations with lockout.

Username: █████████
Password: █████ (first 27 characters)

This image shows my Bash history where I am running my password enumeration script to bruteforce the password.
██████████

You can simply pass your character combination as the first argument to both of the scripts. It will throw 200 as the output if your combination matches.

Note: If you want to fuzz the password for ████ user, make sure to make changes in the pwenum script, because it is only for the ██████████ username.

Until now, I have fuzzed the first 27 characters of password of **███████** and it is **████████**. This isn't the final password, because there are still more characters left to fuzz.

You can take help of my Bash history screenshot that I have attached to see how you can fuzz passwor██████████ for both of the users. Make sure to do double URL encoding in case you want to fuzz with special characters, and for alphabets and numbers, just a simple Bash for loop with {0..9} and {a..z} is enough.

I hope this much information acts as a solid proof-of-concept for this vulnerability.

Thanks,
Binit

I am still enumerating the password for the **██████████** username.

The next 5 characters after 27 characters are found to be **█████████**.

██████

To fuzz with / and + characters, I used their double URL encoded formats, %252F and %252B, respectively.

Good afternoon

Were you able to enumerate the usernames or did you strictly find them via an internet search? If you are able to enumerate the users with the information above we will be able to take it but we will need proof. If you did not enumerate the users we will need a full password in order to take it. 

Keep up the good work! 

@agent-kj7

Hi @agent-kj7,

For enumerating the username, we first need to fuzz the first two characters, because it will display 404 for every character used if you pass a single character.

So, for usernames, I first started with first two known characters: **████** and did the rest on my own.

Now, if you are wondering how I found the first two characters to be **██████████**, I picked it up from the reference material about this vulnerability from PortSwigger at https://portswigger.net/research/hidden-oauth-attack-vectors.

But, when I tried to fuzz it on my own with no known characters too, it actually works. So, I guess there is no need to do full fuzzing for all the characters of the password, because it is time-taking and since we already have enough proofs about this vulnerability existing in this system and also since there is no lockout for even 1000s of different username and password combination trials..

Thanks,
Binit

If you want to enumerate the first two characters of the username, you can simply download the **userenum.sh** script I attached above.

And, then, you can run this command: `for i in {a..z}{a..z}; do echo -n $i" = " && bash userenum.sh "$i"; done`

Here is a picture showing how this works!
███████

Thanks,
Binit

Thank you for the update. You have a default username and possibly the 1st portion of a password. Unless you have them both and can log in OR show that there is no lockout mechanism for logging in, we cannot triage your report. Take the time you need to enumerate the password and I can process this at a much higher severity. For now, I am closing as informative.

Greetings,

We have validated the vulnerability you reported and are preparing to forward this report to the affected DoD system owner for resolution.

Thank you for bringing this vulnerability to our attention!

We will endeavor to answer any questions the system owners may have regarding this report; however, there is a possibility we will need to contact you if they require more information to resolve the vulnerability.

You will receive another status update after we have confirmed your report has been resolved by the system owner. If you have any questions, please let me know.

Thanks again for supporting the DoD Vulnerability Disclosure Program.

Regar███,

The VDP Team

Hi there,

Thanks for letting me know about that! I would love to answer your queries regarding this to resolve the vulnerability.

Thanks,
Binit

Hello @agent-0g,

Upon retesting, I found out that this endpoint has now been removed, without removing the OpenAM instance, which might be referring that the vulnerability has now been patched.

Can you confirm it on your side with the respective site's technical team?

Thanks,
Binit

Good news!

The vulnerability you reported has been resolved and this report is now closed. If you have any further questions or disagree that the report is resolved, please let us know.

Thank you for your time and effort to improve the security of the DoD information network.

Regar███,

The VDP Team

Hello @agent-k9,

It would be great if we can disclose this report. You can hide the images and other attachments, plus the URLs and any other sensitive information.

Also, I hope you would change the report title to "**[CVE-2021-29156 on ForgeRock OpenAm] LDAP Injection in Webfinger Protocol!**"

Thanks,
Binit Ghimire

additional_data.new_title: [CVE-2021-29156 on ForgeRock OpenAm] LDAP Injection in Webfinger Protocol!

activities.message: Thanks for participating in the DoD Vulnerability Disclosure Program. We're publicly disclosing your resolved report at this time.  We also lock the report on the disclosure but feel free to reach out to us at VDP-Questions@dc3.mil if there are any questions, concerns or issues.
Just testing vuln in Locked report feature!
